samples.question: Want to go sounds like one word, want to go?
samples.transcript: Because you are connecting all the speech up. You do that a lot and very naturally. You also use sentence stress, which where you emphasize certain words. that is your coffee. So you are, you are emphasizing that word because that is the most important word. it is very difficult to teach that. It takes a long time to learn. Wow. So you are doing, you are doing very well in that area.

samples.question: What is your favorite food?
samples.transcript: I really love Asian food because I live in England so it is harder to get Asian food around. But I like spicy, flavorful, and like just generally savory food.
samples.transcript_original: Um, I really love Asian food because I live in England so it's harder to get Asian food around. But I like spicy, flavorful, and like just generally savory food.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I really love Asian food because I live in England so it is harder to get Asian food around. But I like spicy, flavorful, and like just generally savory food.

samples.question: Do you cook a lot at home?
samples.transcript: Not as much as I would like to. I would love to cook more because I actually enjoy the process of cooking. But I just cook out of convenience and like because every day I have got to, you know, make sure I get my work done and then cook for my kids, which takes a lot of time. Sometimes we get takeaway, but they like it, you know.

samples.question: How often do you eat fast food?
samples.transcript: I try to eat really healthily, but then I tend to go down the Filet-O-Fish, McDonald's route when I am traveling. So I suppose only once every few months.

samples.question: What is your favorite season of the year?
samples.transcript: Well, I love any time when the sun starts to come out. So around spring or early summer before it gets too hot. You know, I just love a little bit of vitamin C. It makes me happier as well. So that is definitely better than the winter.
samples.transcript_original: Well, um, I love any time when the sun starts to come out. So around spring or early summer before it gets too hot. You know, I just love a little bit of vitamin C. It makes me happier as well. So that is definitely better than the winter.
samples.transcript_cleaned: I love any time when the sun starts to come out. So around spring or early summer before it gets too hot. You know, I just love a little bit of vitamin C. It makes me happier as well. So that is definitely better than the winter.

samples.question: What do you do when it gets too hot in the summer?
samples.transcript: Hide. I tend to also go into any kind of buildings with air conditioning and I have the fan on every night when it is really hot. So yeah, when it gets really hot in the summer, you know, I really need a lot of like fans and you know, kind of just anything I can hold with me when I go out as well.

samples.question: At what time of year do you normally go on holiday?
samples.transcript: I try to go outside of the school holiday season, but because I have kids, you know, we tend to have to go doing, you know, the, the, you know, when, when, when this term breaks, you know, when the school breaks. But, my favorite time of going away would be during Christmas, you know, because, I much prefer to be in a warmer climate when it is really, really cold. So yeah, it is just that time before or after Christmas.
samples.transcript_original: I try to go outside of the school holiday season, but because I have kids, you know, we tend to have to go doing, you know, the, the, you know, when, when, when this term breaks, you know, when the school breaks. samples.question: Have you ever been on holiday somewhere very cold?
samples.transcript: Yes, I love Norway. You know, it was, amazing. It was just, everything was like a picture, a perfect postcard. You know, you could see the fields in the distance and the, what you call them, icebergs. it was an experience, you know, and to rip, to, to ride the husky sled, you know, was also an amazing experience for me. Now let talk about clothes Where do you buy most of your clothes I would like to do you know clothes shopping in the shop but the reality is most of us do it online now You know, and I get my clothes from Zara and ASOS because I just love the hip and trendy but also timeless look.
samples.transcript_original: Yes, I love Norway. You know, it was, um, amazing. It was just, everything was like a picture, a perfect postcard. Um, it was an experience, you know, and to rip, to, to ride the husky sled, you know, was also an amazing experience for me. Now let talk about clothes Where do you buy most of your clothes I would like to do you know clothes shopping in the shop but the reality is most of us do it online now You know, and I get my clothes from Zara and ASOS because I just love the hip and trendy but also timeless look.
samples.transcript_cleaned: Yes, I love Norway. You know, it was, amazing. It was just, everything was like a picture, a perfect postcard. Now let talk about clothes Where do you buy most of your clothes I would like to do you know clothes shopping in the shop but the reality is most of us do it online now You know, and I get my clothes from Zara and ASOS because I just love the hip and trendy but also timeless look.

samples.question: How often do you buy clothes for yourself?
samples.transcript: I buy it more often than I should because I use online shopping and clothes shopping as a form of, you know, like dopamine hit for me. So it is, it is and for me, I love to express myself through my clothes. So, because of that, then I need to find different clothes for different occasions. And so very often.

samples.question: Have you always had the same taste in clothes?

samples.question: Which social media sites do you use?
samples.transcript: I use Instagram and LinkedIn because I feel like I run a business and that is where my target audience are. You know, I built a community through Instagram and then on LinkedIn where I work on my business to business, leads.

samples.question: How much time do you spend on social media?
samples.transcript: Way too much. I should not be spending so much time but I find that it is, once you visit, you know, social media and you post something, it is also about engaging with people So, yeah, a couple of hours a day.
samples.transcript_original: Way too much. I shouldn't be spending so much time but I find that it is, um, once you visit, you know, social media and you post something, it's also about engaging with people So, yeah, a couple of hours a day.
samples.transcript_cleaned: Way too much. I should not be spending so much time but I find that it is, once you visit, you know, social media and you post something, it is also about engaging with people So, yeah, a couple of hours a day.

samples.question: Is there anything you dislike about social media?
samples.transcript: I dislike the addictive quality about it, you know, because so many of us are connected, you know, through a tablet or a device now and social media is our form of communication. So it is becoming, even though it seems like you are being connected to loads and loads of people, the actual quality of your relationships with your immediate sphere, you know, kind of, you know, kind of falls by the way. It kind of falls by the side. So yeah, that is one bad side to it.
samples.transcript_original: I dislike the addictive quality about it, you know, because so many of us are connected, you know, through a tablet or a device now and social media is our form of communication. samples.question: Is that all clear?
samples.transcript: Sure, of course. Here is your.
samples.transcript_original: Sure, of course. Here is your.
samples.transcript_cleaned: Sure, of course. Here is your.

samples.question: Which is something that you could do in other places, but the impact is so much more immediate.
samples.transcript: And you are affecting people in such a big way and affecting a bigger audience as well, whilst you are doing it. And this is something that I am very lucky to be able to do now. And I do not take it for granted and know that the journey for me to get here has been really long. But I am deeply grateful for being given this opportunity. And why I like it also is that to be able to connect with people in a topic that is so personal about mental health and well-being, you know, where in some way or other, you know, we are all struggling in life. Thank you very much.
samples.transcript_original: And you are affecting people in such a big way and affecting a bigger audience as well, whilst you're doing it. samples.question: What factors do you think are important when choosing a career?
samples.transcript: I think it is really, really important that we are interested in what we are doing. And because if you are not interested, then there is absolutely no chance that you are going to be able to have longevity in that career. We should also choose an industry where there is a potential for you to really grow within that industry. Because as we are moving now into the future of work, you know, technology is very quickly replacing people. You know especially with artificial intelligence it threatening a lot of jobs like writing and recruiting and connecting you know with people So we need to look at how you know the industry that you going into has got the potential to go beyond that you know technological capacity What can you bring as a human you know that no technology or anyone could replace you you know if you were to go into it Why do you think some people fail in some careers? I think one of the main drivers I think for people is money. And when you do anything solely because of money, then it will never work. And the reason people fail, I think the biggest reason is because they have failed to align their identity with their work. Because we spend a third of our lives, you know, in work. So a very big proportion of it, you know, needs to feel fulfilled. And it can only be fulfilled if you are, you understand, you know, what you like authentically inside, you know, and then, you know, go into a career. But then the reality is that most people then, you know, jump in and figure it out, explore, and then work it out, you know, in hindsight. I guess that is what life's about.
samples.transcript_original: I think it's really, really important that we are interested in what we're doing. And because if you are not interested, then there's absolutely no chance that you're going to be able to have longevity in that career. We should also choose an industry where there's a potential for you to really grow within that industry. Because as we're moving now into the future of work, you know, technology is very quickly replacing people. But then the reality is that most people then, you know, jump in and figure it out, explore, and then work it out, you know, in hindsight. I guess that's what life's about.

samples.question: In the future, do you think most people will work from home?
samples.transcript: I think it is just, it definitely seems that way anyway, you know, after the pandemic, you know, hybrid working is becoming more common. And a lot of organizations are offering fully remote working now, which a lot of people like, but there are also people who like human interactions, like connections, you know, people who live by themselves or, you know, just need some accountability. So being amongst people could be a good thing. But I think if technology were to replace, you know, a lot of the work, you know, then people would actually eventually do more remote work.
samples.transcript_original: I think it's just, it definitely seems that way anyway, you know, after the pandemic, you know, hybrid working is becoming more common. And a lot of organizations are offering fully remote working now, which a lot of people like, but there are also people who like human interactions, like connections, you know, people who live by themselves or, you know, just need some accountability. So being amongst people could be a good thing. But I think if technology were to replace, you know, a lot of the work, you know, then people would actually eventually do more remote work.

And a lot of organizations are offering fully remote working now, which a lot of people like, but there are also people who like human interactions, like connections, you know, people who live by themselves or, you know, just need some accountability. So being amongst people could be a good thing. But I think if technology were to replace, you know, a lot of the work, you know, then people would actually eventually do more remote work.
